ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: Setting the sticky bit for world-writable directories prevents users from overwriting each others files, whether accidentally or maliciously, and is generally appropriate. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 70-71. Checking that world-writable directories have their sticky bit set.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 7.5 Ensure World-Writable Directories Have Their Sticky Bit Set
ReportItem.description:
"7.5 Ensure World-Writable Directories Have Their Sticky Bit Set" : [FAILED] Setting the sticky bit for world-writable directories prevents users from overwriting each others files, whether accidentally or maliciously, and is generally appropriate. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 70-71. Checking that world-writable directories have their sticky bit set. - error message: The following directories are world writeable and no sticky bit is set :

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: The pam_console PAM module can be configured to allow the user at the console to access various devices including floppy, cdrom, etc. Access to these devices poses a real security risk and should be disabled. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 69-70.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 7.3 Disable User-Mounted Removable File Systems - Check /etc/security/console.perms for user mounted removable file systems.
ReportItem.description: "7.3 Disable User-Mounted Removable File Systems - Check /etc/security/console.perms for user mounted removable file systems." : [PASSED] The pam_console PAM module can be configured to allow the user at the console to access various devices including floppy, cdrom, etc. Access to these devices poses a real security risk and should be disabled. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 69-70.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: With the exception of chroot jails, there is little need for non-administrators to mount unauthorized devices on any partitions that should not contain devices. Checking that fstab has the proper ownership, mode, and immutable attribute set. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 67-69.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 7.2 Add 'nosuid' and 'nodev' Option For Removable Media In /etc/fstab - Check /etc/fstab permissions.
ReportItem.description: "7.2 Add 'nosuid' and 'nodev' Option For Removable Media In /etc/fstab - Check /etc/fstab permissions." : [PASSED] With the exception of chroot jails, there is little need for non-administrators to mount unauthorized devices on any partitions that should not contain devices. Checking that fstab has the proper ownership, mode, and immutable attribute set. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 67-69.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 7.1 Add 'nodev' Option To Appropriate Partitions In /etc/fstab - Check for correct /etc/fstab ownership and mode.
ReportItem.description: "7.1 Add 'nodev' Option To Appropriate Partitions In /etc/fstab - Check for correct /etc/fstab ownership and mode." : [PASSED]

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: Remote logging is critical in the event of an intrusion because it stores logs where the attacker may not be able to remove the traces of their attack. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 6, page 66. NOTE: This query uses a sample IP and will need to be edited to reflect your environment.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-actual-value: The file "/etc/rsyslog.conf" does not contain ^[\s\t]*local7.[*][\s\t]+@
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 6.4 Configure syslogd to Send Logs to a Remote LogHost - Checking that rsyslog is configured properly for local7.*

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: A number of services delineated by table 4t on pp 37 - 40 should be enabled/disabled to provide a more secure RHEL system. ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: A number of services delineated by table 4t on pp 37 - 40 should be enabled/disabled to provide a more secure RHEL system. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 37-40. 4.6 Disable Standard Boot Services - Checking if acpid service is disabled. System daemons without clearly defined purposes should be deactivated. Unnecessary daemons open up potential footholds to vulnerabilities as they are discovered. Services can be enabled on an 'as-needed' basis such as the 'network' or 'dhcpd' service. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 44-47.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: RHEL 5 uses vsftp as the standard, fully supported ftp daemon. Like telnet, ftp data is transmitted unencrypted and should be subsequently disabled. A number of programs with the same functionality along with encryption can be used to replace ftp including scp and sftp. NOTE: This query assures vsftpd is OFF in levels 1-6. If needed CIS recommends ON settings only for levels 3 and 5. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 34-35.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 3.4 Only Enable FTP If Absolutely Necessary - Checking that vsftpd has been disabled on the remote system.
ReportItem.description: "3.4 Only Enable FTP If Absolutely Necessary - Checking that vsftpd has been disabled on the remote system." : [PASSED] RHEL 5 uses vsftp as the standard, fully supported ftp daemon. Like telnet, ftp data is transmitted unencrypted and should be subsequently disabled. A number of programs with the same functionality along with encryption can be used to replace ftp including scp and sftp. NOTE: This query assures vsftpd is OFF in levels 1-6. If needed CIS recommends ON settings only for levels 3 and 5. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 34-35.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: Telnet is a protocol used widely that transmits data unencrypted and should subsequently disabled and replaced by the more secure SSH protocol. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 33-34.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 3.3 Only Enable telnet If Absolutely Necessary - Checking that telnet has been disabled on the remote system.
ReportItem.description: "3.3 Only Enable telnet If Absolutely Necessary - Checking that telnet has been disabled on the remote system." : [PASSED] Telnet is a protocol used widely that transmits data unencrypted and should subsequently disabled and replaced by the more secure SSH protocol. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 33-34.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: CIS recommends initiating a regular policy and procedure to utilize and review system accounting data to monitor system activity and prevent compromise. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 2, page 27. 4.0 Minimize boot Services - Check if 'sysstat' is enabled A number of services delineated by table 4t on pp 37 - 40 should be enabled/disabled to provide a more secure RHEL system. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 37-40. 11.1 Configure and enable the auditd and sysstat services, if possible - Checking if sysstat service is enabled. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 11, pp 101-104.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 2.4 Enable system accounting
ReportItem.description: "2.4 Enable system accounting" : [PASSED] CIS recommends initiating a regular policy and procedure to utilize and review system accounting data to monitor system activity and prevent compromise. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 2, page 27. 4.0 Minimize boot Services - Check if 'sysstat' is enabled A number of services delineated by table 4t on pp 37 - 40 should be enabled/disabled to provide a more secure RHEL system. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 37-40. 11.1 Configure and enable the auditd and sysstat services, if possible - Checking if sysstat service is enabled. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 11, pp 101-104.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: OpenSSH, the popular and free SSH protocol standard, is extremely important for security hardening. Despite the advancement security-wise of SSH over other older protocols for console access and file transfer, a number of important steps should be taken to ensure that SSH has been secured properly. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 2, pp 24-25. NOTE : This entry is now subordinated to a Level II Benchmark issue and no longer a requirement.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 2.3 Configure SSH - Checking if Port is set to 22 and not commented for client.
ReportItem.description: "2.3 Configure SSH - Checking if Port is set to 22 and not commented for client." : [PASSED] OpenSSH, the popular and free SSH protocol standard, is extremely important for security hardening. ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 7.5 Ensure World-Writable Directories Have Their Sticky Bit Set
ReportItem.description:
"7.5 Ensure World-Writable Directories Have Their Sticky Bit Set" : [FAILED] Setting the sticky bit for world-writable directories prevents users from overwriting each others files, whether accidentally or maliciously, and is generally appropriate. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 7, pp 70-71. Checking that world-writable directories have their sticky bit set. - error message: The following directories are world writeable and no sticky bit is set :
/gears owner: 51082, group: 32773, permissions: 0777

Based on the remote operating system, it is possible to determine what the remote system type is (eg: a printer, router, general-purpose computer, etc).
ReportItem.synopsis: It is possible to guess the remote device type.
ReportItem.plugin_output: Remote device type : general-purpose Confidence level : 100

ReportItem.description: Using a combination of remote probes (TCP/IP, SMB, HTTP, NTP, SNMP, etc...), it is possible to guess the name of the remote operating system in use. It is also sometimes possible to guess the version of the operating system.
ReportItem.synopsis: It is possible to guess the remote operating system.
ReportItem.plugin_output:
Remote operating system : Linux Kernel 2.6.32-71.el6.x86_64 on Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 6.1 (Santiago) Confidence Level : 100 Method : LinuxDistribution
The remote host is running Linux Kernel 2.6.32-71.el6.x86_64 on Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 6.1 (Santiago)

ReportItem.pluginName: Linux Daemons with Broken Links to Executables
ReportItem.description:
By examining the '/proc' filesystem on the remote Linux host, Nessus has identified at least one currently-running daemon for which the link to the corresponding executable is broken.
This can occur when the executable associated with a daemon is replaced on disk but the daemon itself has not been restarted. And if the changes are security-related, the system may remain vulnerable to attack until the daemon is restarted.
Alternatively, it could result from an attacker removing files in an effort to hide malicious activity.
ReportItem.plugin_name: Linux Daemons with Broken Links to Executables
ReportItem.solution: Inspect each reported daemon to determine why the link to the executable is broken.
ReportItem.synopsis: A daemon on the remote Linux host may need to be restarted.
ReportItem.plugin_output:
The following daemons are associated with broken links to executables :
- 34158 udp: (/usr/sbin/avahi-daemon) - 3306 tcp: (/usr/libexec/mysqld) - 5353 udp: (/usr/sbin/avahi-daemon)

ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 4.4 Disable GUI Login, If Possible - Check /etc/inittab permissions.
ReportItem.description:
"4.4 Disable GUI Login, If Possible - Check /etc/inittab permissions." : [FAILED] Dedicated servers typically don't need X Windows installation for normal operation. Checking if inittab has the correct ownership and mode is 0600 or more secure. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 43 - 44.
File : /etc/inittab Remote value: owner: root group: root mode: 0644 attr: -------------e- uid: 0 gid: 0 uneven permissions : FALSE Policy value: owner: root group: root mask: 0644 uneven permissions : TRUE

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: A number of services delineated by table 4t on pp 37 - 40 should be enabled/disabled to provide a more secure RHEL system. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 37-40. 4.6 Disable Standard Boot Services - Checking if acpid service is disabled. System daemons without clearly defined purposes should be deactivated. Unnecessary daemons open up potential footholds to vulnerabilities as they are discovered. Services can be enabled on an 'as-needed' basis such as the 'network' or 'dhcpd' service. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 44-47.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: RHEL 5 uses vsftp as the standard, fully supported ftp daemon. Like telnet, ftp data is transmitted unencrypted and should be subsequently disabled. A number of programs with the same functionality along with encryption can be used to replace ftp including scp and sftp. NOTE: This query assures vsftpd is OFF in levels 1-6. If needed CIS recommends ON settings only for levels 3 and 5. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 34-35.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 3.4 Only Enable FTP If Absolutely Necessary - Checking that vsftpd has been disabled on the remote system.
ReportItem.description: "3.4 Only Enable FTP If Absolutely Necessary - Checking that vsftpd has been disabled on the remote system." : [PASSED] RHEL 5 uses vsftp as the standard, fully supported ftp daemon. Like telnet, ftp data is transmitted unencrypted and should be subsequently disabled. A number of programs with the same functionality along with encryption can be used to replace ftp including scp and sftp. NOTE: This query assures vsftpd is OFF in levels 1-6. If needed CIS recommends ON settings only for levels 3 and 5. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 34-35.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: Telnet is a protocol used widely that transmits data unencrypted and should subsequently disabled and replaced by the more secure SSH protocol. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 3, pp 33-34.

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: CIS recommends initiating a regular policy and procedure to utilize and review system accounting data to monitor system activity and prevent compromise. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 2, page 27. 4.0 Minimize boot Services - Check if 'sysstat' is enabled A number of services delineated by table 4t on pp 37 - 40 should be enabled/disabled to provide a more secure RHEL system. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 4, pp 37-40. 11.1 Configure and enable the auditd and sysstat services, if possible - Checking if sysstat service is enabled. ref. https://community.cisecurity.org/download/?redir=/linux/CIS_RHEL_5.0-5.1_Benchmark_v1.1.2.pdf Ch. 11, pp 101-104.
ReportItem.cm:compliance-check-name: 2.4 Enable system accounting

ReportItem.cm:compliance-info: OpenSSH, the popular and free SSH protocol standard, is extremely important for security hardening. This plugin reports a device's hostname collected via SSH or WMI.
ReportItem.synopsis: It is possible to determine the remote system hostname.
ReportItem.plugin_output: Hostname : spongebob

ReportItem.description:
One or more instances of Oracle's (formerly Sun's) Java Runtime Environment (JRE) is/are installed on the remote host. This may include private JREs bundled with the Java Development Kit (JDK).
Note that this plugin does not detect non-Oracle JRE instances such as OpenJDK, GCJ, IBM Java, etc.
ReportItem.synopsis: There is a Java runtime environment installed on the remote Unix host.
ReportItem.plugin_output:
The following instance of Oracle's JRE is installed on the remote host :
Path : /usr/openv/java/ Version : 1.6.0_45
